report_title: Arcade, Food & Entertainment Complexes in the US
executive_summary: The arcade, food and entertainment complex industry has seen revived interest from consumers in recent years due to nostalgia trends. Enhanced food and beverage offerings combined with visually appealing venues have boosted popularity. Despite higher input costs from semiconductor shortages and inflation pressuring profits, revenue is forecast to grow at a 1.7% CAGR to $4.8 billion by end of 2024, including a 1.3% gain in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Reevaluating entertainment complexes to attract previous customers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many businesses have been able to bring back some of their previous customers from decades ago who are now adults by reevaluating what entertainment complexes can be. Alcoholic beverage and food sales have played a more significant role because of their intrinsic value and ability to attract older consumers to visit arcades and spend more time and money on games.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Dave & Buster's expansion with capital investment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Dave & Buster's Entertainment has been a leader in this segment, expanding significantly in the current period with the backing of an influx of capital investment. Although overall revenue grew over the five-year period, the sharp contraction it endured due to the pandemic's economic effects led to a fall in profit in 2020 that was partially offset the following year.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer spending growth to benefit arcades
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumer spending will grow, benefiting arcades, food and entertainment complexes as expenditure on food and entertainment rises. Growth will be driven by sustained consumer interest in unique, immersive experiences as arcades increasingly implement augmented reality technology. Revenue is expected to climb at a 2.2% CAGR to $6.4 billion through 2029.

Falling interest and foot traffic have led arcade, food and entertainment complexes to leverage online platforms creatively to re-engage their audience. By using social media, these businesses have expanded their reach and attracted new demographics. Dave & Buster's virtual world in Roblox engages young gamers and increases brand visibility.

The allure of retro games from their childhood captivates nostalgic adults, encouraging them to visit these venues. Vintage arcade cabinets and classic gaming consoles help mitigate expenses associated with newer machines. Smaller, themed establishments like arcade bars have gained popularity by offering adults a social gaming environment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising input costs slowing profit growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Semiconductor and electronic component shortages, exacerbated by supply chain disruptions and inflation, have led to increased costs for game systems essential to these businesses. Despite these challenges, increased consumer spending has helped sustain the revenue stream.

Arcade, food and entertainment complexes target adult heads of households by elevating their food and drink menus to cater to consumers looking for more sophisticated options while their kids enjoy the facilities. Promotions like meal deals help improve foot traffic.

industry_definition: Arcade, food and entertainment complexes include businesses primarily operating video game arcades and game-focused family entertainment centers. Arcades rent or purchase card- or coin-operated arcade games that customers play for a fee. These businesses also typically sell food and beverages. Businesses that mainly focus on gambling games, billiards, miniature golf and other larger-scale or outdoor amusements are not included in this industry.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: The high maintenance costs for entertainment complexes make it difficult to capture a large share of the market. The mixture of capital and labor costs necessary to maintain quality and service creates difficulties for smaller complexes.

Competition among complexes for consumers creates difficulty in establishing a sizable presence in this industry. Consumers have different tastes and priorities when engaging in leisure activities, making establishing a large market presence a challenge for a newcomer.

The popularity of the retro-style arcade complexes has enabled invigorated attendance. Arcade, food and entertainment complexes benefit from this trend, thriving on the public's interest in revisiting nostalgic experiences

Competition from new gaming technologies will accelerate. As new console adoption increases, arcades will incorporate them, as well as other innovative trends like AR and VR, in their complexes to capitalize on this growth.
Only one company maintains more than a 5.0% share of the market. The wide availability of capital, coupled with a hybrid business model, enables Dave & Buster's to dominate the market.
The growth in consumer-adjacent options beyond games. Recovery is underway, thanks to new changes to the dine-in and beverage services menu, which has supported attendance nationwide.

Industry associations like the American Amusement Machine Association (AAMA) and the Amusement and Music Operators Association provide crucial support to arcades. They maintain game standards and protect consumers through systems like the Parental Advisory System.

market_segmentation.segment_description: A withdrawal is reflected in consumers aged 36 and older that play video games or participate in gaming as a recreational activity. This age group is the most sensitive to changes in the overall economy, as they have the highest income levels but also the least leisure time. With the acceleration of technology, some older consumers with higher disposable income opt to bring the gaming experience to their homes instead of investing time at entertainment complexes.
This segment includes consumers from the ages of 18 to 35 that participate in gaming and captures the broad definition of young adults.

Traditionally known as adolescents, consumers at or below the age of 17 make up this segment. This age group has seen the largest growth among all other consumer groups, and the industry's push to make entertainment complexes feel retro is paying off. As adolescents have the most leisure time available, they will be the likeliest group to participate in gaming while also having an opportunity to socialize with similar aged people. Even as advancements in technology introduced newer gaming consoles, the allure of classic games coupled with large amounts of leisure time helped fuel growth in this market segment.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment is largely made up of admissions into the entertainment complex itself. A complex could charge customers a certain price that varies depending on either the time of day or the type of activity being pursued by the consumer.

Games and ride admissions include products like card- and coin-operated arcade games. Game genres include sports, racing and FPS (first-person shooter) games. Admissions can include payment for specific games within the complex, with certain entertainment complexes adding charges for playing a particular game. Some arcades are adding VR attractions at an additional cost.

The food and beverages segment includes snacks, soft drinks and vending machine products. Additional items incorporated in recent years include dine-in services and alcoholic beverages sold to adults. The increased demand for alcoholic beverages and full-course meals within entertainment complexes has helped sustain growth for this product segment over the past few years. The impact of inflation and price hikes, particularly on food and alcohol, has provided the industry with further revenue and has helped fuel revenue growth.

Event services include any events or parties hosted for individuals or large groups of customers. Additional services are offered to corporate events and parties, for example certain offers allow for an unlimited gaming experience or full rental of the facility for a period of time. The effects of inflationary pressures have significantly affected corporate demand, as higher interest rates continue to constrain corporate clients' fiscal flexibility.

Merchandise sales, parking services and game repair servicing are included in this segment. There was a marked decline in demand for parking services and merchandise as consumers shifted their disposable income away from travel and recreational goods during the pandemic.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita disposable income determines an individual's ability to purchase goods or services. As per capita disposable income rises, more consumers can allocate expenditures toward leisure. The products offered by arcades and entertainment complexes are discretionary in nature. Therefore as disposable income rises, consumers become more likely to spend money on trips to arcade, food and entertainment complexes.

business_locations.location_description: More than a quarter of the national population resides in the Southeast. The high concentration of establishments in the region is driven by factors like warm weather, a diverse population, and proximity to major population hubs like Florida. Major urban centers and favorable climate conditions make the Southeast an attractive location for expansion, leading to a higher density of entertainment complexes in the region.

Notable expansion of establishments in the West was the result of proximity to, large population hubs and cities with prominent gaming companies. California has led in this department, with the presence of large gaming centers in cities like Los Angeles and excellent weather providing multiple incentives for entertainment complexes in this region.

The Great Lakes region has a strong presence, supported by varied geography and numerous population centers. Ohio stands out with its large urban areas and diverse demographic, fueling establishment growth. The absence of major metropolitan hubs is balanced by smaller population centers. Although there are no major population hubs like in other regions, Ohio is the closest example, with large population centers and a diverse population that has provided an accelerant for establishments in the region.

Thanks to its geographic advantages and diversified population, the Mid-Atlantic region remains a prime location for arcades, food and entertainment complexes. High costs are offset by opportunities in major hubs like New York. Despite higher operational costs, the region's strategic location and demographic diversity attract businesses looking to capitalize on the market and open their own arcade, food and entertainment complexes.

Certain geographic areas like the Plains and Rocky Mountains show significantly lower levels of establishment concentration. These regions lack notable population hubs, making them less attractive for entertainment complexes. Heightened costs, longer distances between arcade, food and entertainment complexes and fewer potential consumers contribute to the low popularity and reduced profitability in these areas.

regulations_points.regulation_description: To ensure compliance with labor and accessibility laws, food and entertainment complexes must adhere to the Fair Labor Standards Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act. These laws protect the rights of employees and customers with disabilities. By adhering to these regulations, businesses create more inclusive environments, enhancing customer satisfaction and fostering a diverse workforce.

The Parental Advisory System (PAS), managed by the American Amusement Machine Association and the Amusement and Music Operators Association, provides content ratings for arcade games. Using green, yellow and red indicators, it categorizes games based on suitability regarding violence, sexual content and language.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Life Cycle Stage: mature, Revenue Volatility Level: very high, Industry Assistance Level: low - steady, Competition Level: high - increasing
Concentration Level: low, Globalization Level: low - steady
There are few legal barriers within the industry. Traditional licensing, such as building permits, are necessary to comply with state and local regulations, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The average start-up cost of opening a facility is high due to expensive capital and maintenance costs associated with operating a facility. Also, acquiring games for the facility provides more expenses for industry operators.

basis_points.basis_description: The level of competition is high within the industry, as operators compete for a specific niche of customers to generate revenue. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated this trend since operators had to adhere to local health guidelines.

Arcade, Food and Entertainment Complexes require large amounts of capital for an efficient start-up. The capital costs of opening and maintaining a facility are considered one of the biggest to attract new customers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: HIGH MARGINAL COSTS LIMIT THE POTENTIAL FOR NEW ENTRANTS
concentration_points.concentration_description: The initial start-up costs of opening and maintaining an entertainment complex are high, limiting the opportunity for new operators to enter the market. Though the marginal costs are relatively stable for a mature establishment, the short-term costs are high for any new competition, contributing to a low concentration level.

One of the points of emphasis for successful operators within the industry is creating and maintaining a steady connection between what consumers want and what the establishment has to offer. If consumers in a certain region are primarily concentrated in a particular age group, that may signify a tilt toward a certain game genre and require a different approach.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: INCREASED DEMAND FOR LABOR RAISES WAGE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Although capital costs are one of the highest costs for any arcade and entertainment complex, the increasing demand for employees to run and maintain facilities has caused wage costs to rise and remain a core expenditure for complex operators. This trend has caused industry complexes to prioritize part-time employees, which could cut wage costs and keep operating costs under control.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: HIGH OPERATING COSTS REMAIN PROBLEMATIC FOR PROFIT
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The constant need for maintenance, upgrades and other facility enhancements results in a large operational cost for entertainment complexes. Although the industry has offered an increasingly diversified set of products, it has also experienced heightened input costs, which have been detrimental to industry profit growth.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: STUBBORN RENTAL COSTS REMAIN A STICKING POINT FOR ARCADE COMPLEXES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many smaller arcade complexes do not own their arcade facilities; they must rent the space from larger landlords. Rental costs have risen as inflationary pressures have intensified over the last few years. In highly populated areas, particularly cities, rental costs are much higher. This results in larger amounts of capital allocated toward renting the space for an entertainment complex.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Arcade, Food and Entertainment Complexes require large amounts of capital for an efficient start-up. The capital costs of opening and maintaining a facility are considered one of the biggest to attract new customers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Arcade, Food and Entertainment Complexes are Dependent on Consumer Demand
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since arcades rely on consumers being interested in playing games and in-person socializing, there is high volatility. Consumer confidence, like the availability of disposable income, is dependent upon broader macroeconomic conditions. Availability of disposable income determines fiscal flexibility, which plays a role in consumer demand since consumers are less inclined to visit arcades.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Adaptation of New Gaming Consoles Diversifies Consumer Base
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: With new consoles like the PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X being released, the industry has been able to diversify its game product arsenal while also appealing to younger consumers. The addition of newer gaming consoles has enabled the industry to diversify not only its consumer base but also its product offering within gaming, which widens appeal to multiple age categories.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Arcade Complexes Add Eating and Drinking Options to Expand the Definition of Entertainment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The expansion of dine-in and drink options at arcade complexes allowed for the industry to widen its outreach beyond younger consumers and attract older consumers to establishments. For many consumers, a visit to an arcade complex goes beyond the gaming experience and serves as a place of socialization. The industry has taken note of this trend in its focus on expanding food and beverage offerings.

FAQs.question: Are your company's prices competitive with both direct competitors and alternative forms of entertainment?
FAQs.answer: Entertainment complexes primarily compete with home-based entertainment options, where the costs are significantly lower per use, but in the long run, more expensive.

FAQs.question: Is your revenue sensitive to changes in discretionary spending?
FAQs.answer: When consumers do not have enough money for entertainment purposes, then they do not pursue entertainment options, making this industry sensitive to discretionary spending.

FAQs.question: How does your company use location to add value and offer unique products and services to your consumers?
FAQs.answer: If located in a city, operators may offer further food and beverage options to consumers. If located in a suburban area, then operators may cater to local residents. Arcades and entertainment centers that have larger locations fare better than smaller operators. This is due to larger areas being able to accommodate more customers.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to use rental agreements to save on equipment expenses?
FAQs.answer: Arcades commonly enter into rental agreements with arcade game companies to lower equipment costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: Arcades and entertainment centers use many part-time employees in this industry to save on wage costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company updated facilities to enhance the consumer experience?
FAQs.answer: Many centers have given their facilities upgrades to enhance the consumer experience, especially for younger consumers.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: Membership agreements and passes are not subject to state or federal regulations.

FAQs.question: Are you subject to specific franchising laws that may hinder growth?
FAQs.answer: There are no specific franchising laws that affect this industry.

FAQs.question: How do you manage cash flow and financial planning to ensure steady funding for operational expenses?
FAQs.answer: Proper cash flow management is essential in a capital-intensive industry like arcades to maintain infrastructure.

FAQs.question: Does your company have to purchase new equipment on an annual basis?
FAQs.answer: Arcades and entertainment centers typically invest in new equipment only when needed, which makes depreciation in this industry very low.

FAQs.question: What costs can you cut back on? Are there any systems you can use to effectively control costs?
FAQs.answer: Amusement arcades that can quickly and efficiently supply the market with popular video games tend to have the highest profit margins. Similarly, those that remove less popular games do not waste funds on their maintenance.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? What are the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: With a large number of new games entering the market, amusement arcade firms need to implement technology and game changes to remain ahead of their competitors.

FAQs.question: Are you located in a densely populated area? How close are you to your nearest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Location decisions are crucial for industry operators and being geographically close to popular locations, such as malls or shopping precincts, tends to maximize an operator's potential customer base.

FAQs.question: Do you track the amount of time spent on leisure and sports? How do you mitigate the threat of declining leisure time?
FAQs.answer: With more leisure time, individuals have more opportunities to spend money on discretionary activities, including trips to arcades or family entertainment centers.

FAQs.question: How has increased demand for home gaming systems affected your revenue? What unique services can you offer to combat this trend?
FAQs.answer: Video games and mobile gaming devices comprise stiff competition for the industry, especially when technological change is high.

FAQs.question: Do you track trends in per capita disposable income?
FAQs.answer: The products offered by amusement arcades are discretionary in nature.

FAQs.question: How much does a customer usually spend in one visit to your arcade?
